Qualified personnel are those that meet the training requirements established in the First Level Hazard Review documents of the NIST Engineering Laboratory additive manufacturing projects . All required training must be completed before being considered qualified to operate the EOS M270 system. Users of the EOS M270 system must follow the operating instructions, the safety data sheets, and the parameter sheets established for the system . These materials are found in the EOS manu als located with the system. Users of the EOS M270 system must observe and follow the safety warnings posted in the laboratory and provided in the manuals and other safety documentation. Project staff must wear the required protective equipment appropriat e for the activity . Depending on the activity (see the specific standard operating procedures), personal protective equipment (PPE) for the additive manufacturing projects includes: - NIOSH full face body -covering clothing (Nomex) if handling Al, Ti, or other reactive materials - fire retardant hood if handling Al, Ti or other reactive materials - protective gloves (fire retardant gloves for Al, Ti, or other reactive m aterials; latex gloves otherwise) - conductive (anti -static) shoes or heal strap used in conjunction with a grounded anti-static floor pad - steel-toed safety shoes - safety glasses The EOS M270 system has several built -in safety features (e.g., chamber door interlocks, room air monitoring, inert gas monitoring, laser readiness indicator, laser -safe window, anti-static floor pad, grounded system components, emergency stop circuit, explosion- proof water -filled vacuum system) . Project staff must not disable or over -ride the built -in safety features of the system. Flammable materials should not be stored in the working area around the machine . Sources of ignition and electrostatic discharge s hould be eliminated and avoided as much as possible. The appropriate inert gas must be used depending on the metal powder in the chamber - nitrogen with stainless steel powder and argon with titanium or aluminum powder . The inert gas monitor on the front of the control panel indicates the appropriate setting (N2 for nitrogen, Ar for argon, O for off). Working with metal powders requires several safety precautions, including respiratory protection, protective gloves, non- sparking tools and equipment, ant i-static grounding, and careful manipulation to prevent dust clouds . See specific procedures below for working with metal powders. AM.SOP.2 - Storage of Metal Powder (Revised: 12/20/11) Powder must be kept in original vendor -supplied tightly closed co ntainers. 31 These containers are then stored in a metal flammable storage cabinet that is cool, dry, and ventilated. Cabinet must protect against physical damage and be isolated from sources of heat, ignition, and moisture. Whatever powder cannot be saved for recovery or recycling should be vacuumed up with the EOS wet separator. AM.SOP.3 - Handling of Metal Powder and Methods for Inserting Metal Powder into Measurement Equipment3 (Revised: 12/20/11) In addition to handling metal powder during EOS system set -up and part removal, powder samples will be placed into microscope slides (for optical inspection) or small sealed vials for transport to mass spectrometry or optical emission machines. Staff handling metal powders must wear appropriate PPE . This includes NIOSH full face respirator if handling Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; protective gloves (fire retardant gloves for Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; latex gloves otherwise); and conductive shoes or anti -static heal strap. Powder should only be manipulated with non- sparking tools and equipment. Work surface must be grounded and tools bonded. Care must be taken to manipulate powder slowly, to prevent the form ation of a dust cloud. Heat sources, water, oxidizers, acids, and alkalis should be avoided in the presence of powder. The nozzle from an operating EOS wet separator must be held close -by whenever powder manipulation (such as pouring powder into measurement sieves) might result in a dust cloud. AM.SOP.4 - Cleanup of Spilled Metal Powder (Revised: 12/20/11) Staff cleaning up spilled metal powders must wear appropriate PPE . This includes NIOSH full face res pirator if handling Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; protective gloves (fire retardant gloves for Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; la tex gloves otherwise); and conductive shoes or anti -static heal strap. Remove all sources of ignition. Ventilate area of spill. Avoid contact with water. Clean up spills in a manner that does not disperse dust into the air, using non- sparking tools. Recovered bulk powder should be placed into original vendor -supplied storage container. Remaining non- recoverable powder should be vacuumed up using EOS wet separator. 3 Measurement equipment may include mechanical sieves, microscopes, mass spectrometers, and optical emissio n spectrometers. 32 AM.SOP.5 - Disposal of Metal Powder (Revised: 12/20/11) Any powder remnants that cannot be reclaimed for reuse should be vacuumed up with the EOS wet separator. When full, the EOS wet separator should be emptied according to the maintenance instructions in the EOS accessories manual. Per guidance from the NIST Office of Safety, Health, and Envi ronment (OSHE), the resulting metal powder sludge from the cleaned EOS wet separator should be stored in a sealed plastic bag inside a metal container with a closed lid until picked up for disposal by NIST janitorial staff. AM.SOP.6 - Emergency Response for Fire Involving Metal Powder (Revised: 12/20/11) In case of fire or ignition of metal powder, first get yourself and all nearby personnel out of the danger area. Then activate the nearest fire alarm (located in the hallway of NIST Building 304) and contact NIST Emergency Services by calling x2222 from a phone outside the danger area . Leave the building using the nearest safe exit and gather at the designated meeting point. For extinguisher -trained personnel only: - Activate the nearest fire alarm (l ocated in the hallway of NIST Building 304) or call x2222 before using the extinguisher. - If the fire is small, use ONE Class D extinguisher in an attempt to put the fire out. - Use only ONE extinguisher, and then leave the building using the nearest safe exit. Important Safety Note: Use only Class D fire extinguishers for fires involving metal powder . Do not use water due to the reactivity of the metal powder with water. AM.SOP.7 - Emergency Shutdown of EOS System (Revised: 12/20/11) In case of emergenc y, press the red Emergency Stop button on the front of the system control panel to stop the EOS M270 system immediately. Emergency situations that would require an emergency shutdown of the EOS system may include NIST Building 304 water leaks that impact Room 118, Building 304 fire evacuations, weather emergencies that require evacuation or shelter -in-place, or failure of one or more system safety controls. Occupants must follow the instructions in the NIST Occupant Em ergency Plan. AM.SOP.8 - EOS System Startup (Revised: 12/20/11) Before system startup, confirm that the power transformer is in the "On" position. Turn on the machine using the main switch and the control voltage button. Once the chiller starts and the computer boots, log in to the control computer and start the PSW control program . Before proceeding further, conduct the oxygen sensor test by holding the blue O2 Sensor Test button until the computer screen indicates "Successful." The system pistons for the (1) recoating blade, (2) build platform, (3) collector platform, and (4) dispenser platform must be "homed" each time the system is started (four separate pistons) . This must be done with the chamber door in the closed position and the access releas e button lighting up red (Note: Green means "safe" and the system cannot move; Red means "active"). 33 The build chamber must be cleaned prior to the start of each build to remove the fine metal condensate that is created during system operation . With the b uild chamber door open, clean the metal condensate from the build chamber walls, ceiling, and door gasket using a paper shop towel wetted with an all -purpose cleaner . Since the metal condensate is flammable if given an ignition source, anti -static safety shoes or an anti -static heal - strap used in conjunction with a grounded anti -static floor pad must be worn when cleaning the metal condensate from steel or other non- reactive metals . When cleaning the metal condensate from aluminum, titanium, or other reac tive metals, a NIOSH full face respirator and body -covering flame -retardant clothing (Nomex), gloves, and hood must be worn in addition to the anti -static PPE. The lens cover of the laser also must be cleaned prior to the start of each build. With the build chamber door open, clean the lens cover with the lens cleaning cloths wetted with high purity (99.99%) alcohol . Use a flashlight to ensure that no streaks remain. Per guidance from t he NIST Office of Safety, Health, and Environment (OSHE), the soiled paper towels from cleaning the metal condensate from the build chamber and the lens cloths from cleaning the lens cover should be placed in a sealed plastic bag inside a metal container w ith a closed lid until picked up for disposal by NIST janitorial staff. AM.SOP.9 - Preparation of Build Platform (Revised: 12/20/11) Prior to inserting the build platform into the chamber, raise the build platform to the top position and vacuum any remaining metal powder from the bolt holes. Prior to inserting the build platform into the chamber, clean off excess machine oils from the build platform using paper shop towels wetted with an all -purpose cleaner . Steel -toed safety shoes are necessary when lifting or moving heavy build platform s. In addition, the lifting trolley supplied by EOS is available for use when large parts are fabricated on the build platform . When mounting the build platform , first insert the bolts loosely (do not tighten) . Turn on the build platform heating using the PSW control program . Tighten the bolts only after the build platform temperature reaches 80 ºC. Prior to the start of each build, the build platform must be leveled and positioned to have the appropriate relation with the recoating blade . Level the build platform according to the instructions provided in the EOS operations manual, first leveling the Y -axis with a feeler gauge (back to front), then leveling the X -axis with a dial indicator (left to right) . Position the height of the build platform with respect to the recoating blade according to the instructions in the EOS operations manual based on the thicknes s of the feeler gauge and the layer thickness of the material used (.02 mm for stainless steel) . Note that all system operations with the PSW control program are done using mm units. Prior to the start of each build, the supply of metal powder must be fi lled, leveled, and compacted . Staff handling metal powders must wear appropriate PPE . This includes NIOSH full face respirator if handling Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; protective gloves (fire retardant gloves for Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; latex gloves otherwise); and conductive shoes or anti -static heal strap. Additional metal powder should be added (as needed for the spec ific build) by first lowering the powder dispenser platform, and then slowly pouring the metal powder from 34 the vendor -supplied container into the dispenser platform while holding the nozzle of the operating EOS wet separator close- by. Care should be taken to minimize the potential for a dust cloud. Dust can be reduced by lowering the dispenser platform a small amount at a time and filling the powder dispenser in increments . The desiccant pack should be removed from the stored metal powder prior to filling the dispenser . The vendor - supplied containers are custom -sized to fit within the system build chamber during filling of the dispenser platform . After adding the metal powder to the dispenser platform, vacuum any extraneous powder from the outside of the container, replace the desiccant pack in the container, and reseal the container for later use. Prior to each build, the metal powder in the dispenser platform must be leveled by hand using a non- sparking tool . In addition, the metal powder must be com pacted by pressing down on the powder with the non- sparking tool . Finally the powder dispenser platform should be raised and the final leveling of the powder done using the system recoating blade. Once the build platform and metal powder supply are prepa red (and the build chamber and lens cover are cleaned), the chamber door should be closed and the inert gas flow started using the PSW control program to pre -flood the chamber . Confirm that the gas flow meters indicate that the inert gas flow has begun. AM.SOP.10 - EOS System Operation (Revised: 12/20/11) The EOS is designed to operate for long periods unattended. Typical build times range from several hours to several days, depending on the numbers of parts and the part sizes . A typical small build ma y be prepared during the day and run unattended overnight to fabricate the parts . If an error or other problem occurs during operation (such as a power outage or other interruption), sufficient built -in controls and safety features are incorporated to hal t the system in a safe status. Care must be taken during the offline data preparation steps of a build to ensure that in- process fabricated parts do not come loose from the build platform . If this happens, the recoating blade will contact the "floating" part and crash (shut down) the build, possibly damaging the ceramic recoating blade. When fabricating large parts, extra care must be taken to ensure that sufficient support structures are incorporated to fix the in- process part to the build platform . AM.SOP.11 - Part Removal and Post Processing (Revised: 12/20/11) After completion of a build, parts must be removed according to the instructions in the EOS operations manual. When removing parts from the build chamber, staff must wear appropriate PPE . Th is includes NIOSH full face respirator if handling Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; protective gloves (fire retardant gloves for Al, Ti, or other reactive materials; latex gloves otherwise); and conductive shoes or anti -static heal strap. Upon opening the build chamber door, allow the oxygen level to increase to 18% (indicated by the PSW control program) and conduct an oxygen sensor test by holding the blue O2 Sensor Test button until the computer screen indicates "Successful." Excess powder on the build chamber door, door frame, and face of the machine should be vacuumed into the EOS wet separator. 35 The metal powder should be carefully moved using non- sparking hand tools from the build platform and the collector platform back into the powder dispenser (moving powder left to right in the build chamber) . The unused powder should be run through the sieve tray as it is moved back into the powder dispenser to remove extraneous bits of fused powder . Care should be taken to prevent a dust cloud from forming as the powder is moved. The nozzle of the operating EOS wet separator should be held close -by to collect any dust cloud. Steel -toed safety shoes are necessary when removing heavy build platform s. In addition, the lifting trolley supplied by EOS is available for use when large parts are fabricated on the build platform . The resulting parts should be heat -treated while still fixed to the buil d platform using a programmable oven according to the instructions in the EOS operations manual . Heat resistant gloves must be used when removing post -processed parts from the heat treat oven. Parts should be allowed to cool before removing from the oven if acceptable for the specified heat treatment. Following the heat treat, the fabricated parts must be removed from the build platform using either electrical discharge machining (EDM) or metal sawing operations, both available as a service from NIST Fabr ication Services . If the parts are cut from the build platform while "dry" (typically not the case if EDM is used), machining operators must wear appropriate respiratory PPE (NIOSH full -face respirator or powered air purifying respirator (PAPR) with P100 HEPA cartridge) due to the potential for embedded metal powder remaining inside the part. Once released from the build platform , supporting material typically must be removed from the fabricated parts using a variety of hand finishing operations, typicall y involving bench vises and hand tools . Protective gloves should be worn as needed during these hand finishing operations. The final step to complete the fabricated parts is to shot peen the parts with steel or ceramic balls to compact the outer surfaces of the parts, add (desirable) compressive stresses, and improve the surface finish of the parts. The used build platform s must be machined flat for future reuse for new parts . Suitable grinding operations are available as a service from NIST Fabrication Services. AM.SOP.12 - Normal Shutdown of EOS System (Revised: 12/20/11) After completion of a build, removal of the parts, and (preferred but optional prior to normal shutdown) cleaning of the build chamber to prepare for the next build, the system can be powered down by (1) ending the PSW control program, (2) shutting down the control computer, and (3) turning off the machine main switch. After shutting off the machine main switch, watch for the three lights in the (front left) cabinet to flash red indicating complete shutdown. AM.SOP.13 - Maintenance of EOS System and Accessories (Revised: 12/20/11) The EOS system and its accessories must be maintained according to the instructions in the EOS operations and accessories manuals . In particular, specif ic guidance is provided for maintaining the chiller unit, the recirculation system, the wet separator, and the recoating blade. 36 NIST staff should never attempt to modify, fix, or maintain the EOS laser system or to access the laser delivery path . Laser covers and laser safety controls are to remain intact for all NIST operations . All maintenance of the laser system is to be performed by a trained EOS service technician during service visits . A laser safety warning sign is to be placed at the entrance to the laboratory when the EOS service technician is working on the laser system. Appropriate PPE must be worn when replacing the ceramic re -coater blade, including protective gloves, respiratory protection, and anti -static safety shoes or anti -static heal - strap used in conjunction with a grounded anti -static floor pad . The sieve tray for the metal powder should be in place over the dispenser platform when replacing the re -coater blade to ensure that the small bolts holding the blade cover do not fall into the metal powder. Important Safety Note: Replacing the dirty filters to maintain the recirculation system is viewed as potentially the most hazardous operation necessary in using the EOS system . The recirculation system holds two large filters (top and bottom) that filter the inert gas flow and collect fine metal condensate from the build chamber . Each of the filters is grounded to the cabinet of the recirculation system to reduce the chance for static discharge . Due to the high flammability and quantity of metal condensate in these filters, full flame -retardant clothing, gloves, and hood and the anti -static PPE are mandatory when changing the filters of the recirculation system, regardless of the type of metal powders used . At least two NIST project staff must be present to perform the filter change, with full flame -retardant PPE worn by everyone and no exposed skin visible for anyone in the metal additive manufacturing laboratory . The filter change must be perfo rmed according to the instructions in the EOS accessories manual . Since the filters are bulky, the lifting trolley supplied by EOS should be used in removing the old filter and in installing the new filter . Once a filter is removed, the filter should be wetted with water to further prevent static discharge and the dampened filter must be placed in a large plastic bag for disposal - the filter cannot be reused or stored. AM.SOP.14 - Use, Storage, and Care of PPE (Revised: 12/20/11) Each project member sh all be issued a full -face respirator (based on the results of the fitting by the NIST Safety Office) and hood(s) for the powered air purifying respirator (PAPR) units for their individual use . The respirators and hoods will be labeled for identification p urposes. The batteries for the powered air purifying respirator (PAPR) units shall remain plugged in to the chargers when not in use. Full-face respirators are to be cleaned with antiseptic wipes on a regular basis as instructed by the NIST Safety Office to remove any accumulations or potential respiratory hazards (e.g., metal powder) . Cleaned respirators shall be stored in individual sealed (ziplock -type) plastic bags to keep them ready for the next use. Full-face respirators are to be tested (both inh aling and exhaling) prior to each use to ensure that the cartridges are not plugged. Replacement cartridges will be kept on -hand so that work is not delayed. The two anti -static heel straps provided with the EOS M270 system shall remain in the metal addi tive manufacturing laboratory. 37 Fire retardant body -covering clothing and protective gloves (both fire -retardant and latex) in a variety of sizes shall be available in the metal additive manufacturing laboratory. The full-face respirators, PAPR hoods, fire retardant clothing, protective gloves, and anti - static heel straps are to be stored in the designated PPE cabinet(s) within the metal additive manufacturing laboratory . Specifically, these items are not to be removed from the laboratory so that any trace amounts of metal powder are contained and not spread to other areas unintentionally. AM.SOP.15 - Use and Handling of Compressed Gas (Revised: 12/20/11) Project staff must be familiar with safe use and handling of compressed gas . General safety informa tion on gas cylinder handling is provided on the NIST Safety web site and is covered by NIST Health and Safety Instruction ( HSI) No. 5. Direct exposure to high- pressure gas from a nozzle can perforate your skin and can damage soft tissues of the body, such as your eyes . High flow rates cause noise that can produce hearing loss . Rapid release of gas can lead to oxygen depletion and suffocation. Safety glasses with side shields and protective footwear must be worn during all phases of gas cylinder operation, including storage, use, relocation, and disposal. The EOS system requires Argon gas cylinders only when building parts from aluminum and titanium powders . When bui lding parts from stainless steel powder, the EOS system generates the Nitrogen inert atmosphere in the build chamber using a built -in function (i.e., Nitrogen gas cylinders are not necessary). The EOS system includes built- in oxygen sensors to monitor the system environment (both within the build chamber and in the machine cabinet), as well as a visible/audible warning system to warn of potential hazardous situations. As an extra precaution, an additi onal oxygen sensor and alarm system will be installed in the laboratory to monitor the oxygen concentration in the room. Gas cylinders should be securely fastened to a fixed holder at all times (during storage, usage, and disposal) to prevent them from fal ling over . Transport of gas cylinders only should be done using a stable, approved cylinder cart . Gas cylinders are Full , In Use, or Empty, and are tagged with a status coupon to indicate their status . Gas cylinders should be properly capped when not in service. Cylinders with status indicating Full or Empty should be capped by definition. Whenever the cap on the gas cylinder is removed, it is understood to be In Use and the coupon should reflect this status . Any cylinder that has not been used for more than 24 hours is considered to be in storage and must have the regulator removed and a proper cap secured. When the gas cylinder has been emptied, the cylinder status should be changed to indicate Empty and the cylinder should be taken out of service a nd disposed of according to NIST guidelines. Experimental work for the NIST projects will use only powder materials that can be processed in a nitrogen environment for the projected future; no aluminum or titanium powder materials will be used (and so no Argon gas cylinders) until further safety controls are in place and the hazards are reassessed in the future.
